segment.source: Deploy a Windows 10 image using MDT 2013 Update 2 (Windows 10)
segment.target: Deploy a Windows 10 image using MDT 2013 Update 2 (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic will show you how to take your reference image for Windows 10, and deploy that image to your environment using the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT), and MDT 2013 Update 2 specifically.
segment.target: This topic will show you how to take your reference image for Windows 10, and deploy that image to your environment using the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT), and MDT 2013 Update 2 specifically.

segment.source: Deploy a Windows 10 image using MDT 2013 Update 2
segment.target: Deploy a Windows 10 image using MDT 2013 Update 2

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic will show you how to take your reference image for Windows 10, and deploy that image to your environment using the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT), and MDT 2013 Update 2 specifically.
segment.target: This topic will show you how to take your reference image for Windows 10, and deploy that image to your environment using the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT), and MDT 2013 Update 2 specifically.

segment.source: You will prepare for this by creating a MDT deployment share that is used solely for image deployment.
segment.target: You will prepare for this by creating a MDT deployment share that is used solely for image deployment.

segment.source: Separating the processes of creating reference images from the processes used to deploy them in production allows greater control of on both processes.
segment.target: Separating the processes of creating reference images from the processes used to deploy them in production allows greater control of on both processes.

segment.source: You will then configure the deployment share, create a new task sequence, add applications, add drivers, add rules, and configure Active Directory permissions for deployment.
segment.target: You will then configure the deployment share, create a new task sequence, add applications, add drivers, add rules, and configure Active Directory permissions for deployment.

segment.source: For the purposes of this topic, we will use three machines: DC01, MDT01, and PC0005.
segment.target: For the purposes of this topic, we will use three machines: DC01, MDT01, and PC0005.

segment.source: DC01 is a domain controller, MDT01 is a Windows Server 2012 R2 standard server, and PC0005 is a blank machine to which you deploy Windows 10.
segment.target: DC01 is a domain controller, MDT01 is a Windows Server 2012 R2 standard server, and PC0005 is a blank machine to which you deploy Windows 10.

segment.source: MDT01 and PC0005 are members of the domain contoso.com for the fictitious Contoso Corporation.
segment.target: MDT01 and PC0005 are members of the domain contoso.com for the fictitious Contoso Corporation.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: For important details about the setup for the steps outlined in this article, please see Deploy Windows 10 with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit.
segment.target: For important details about the setup for the steps outlined in this article, please see Deploy Windows 10 with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit.

segment.target: figure 1

segment.target: The machines used in this topic.

segment.source: Step 1: Configure Active Directory permissions
segment.target: Step 1: Configure Active Directory permissions

segment.source: These steps will show you how to configure an Active Directory account with the permissions required to deploy a Windows 10 machine to the domain using MDT.
segment.target: These steps will show you how to configure an Active Directory account with the permissions required to deploy a Windows 10 machine to the domain using MDT.

segment.source: These steps assume you have downloaded the sample Set-OUPermissions.ps1 script and copied it to C:SetupScripts on DC01.
segment.target: These steps assume you have downloaded the sample Set-OUPermissions.ps1 script and copied it to C:SetupScripts on DC01.

segment.source: The account is used for Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) to connect to MDT01.
segment.target: The account is used for Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) to connect to MDT01.

segment.source: In order for MDT to join machines into the contoso.com domain you need to create an account and configure permissions in Active Directory.
segment.target: In order for MDT to join machines into the contoso.com domain you need to create an account and configure permissions in Active Directory.

segment.source: On DC01, using Active Directory User and Computers, browse to contoso.com / Contoso / Service Accounts.
segment.target: On DC01, using Active Directory User and Computers, browse to contoso.com / Contoso / Service Accounts.

segment.source: Select the Service Accounts organizational unit (OU) and create the MDTJD account using the following settings:
segment.target: Select the Service Accounts organizational unit (OU) and create the MDTJD account using the following settings:

segment.source: Name: MDTJD
segment.target: Name: MDTJD

segment.source: User logon name: MDTJD
segment.target: User logon name: MDTJD

segment.source: Password: P@ssw0rd
segment.target: Password: P@ssw0rd

segment.source: User must change password at next logon: Clear
segment.target: User must change password at next logon: Clear

segment.source: User cannot change password: Select
segment.target: User cannot change password: Select

segment.source: Password never expires: Select
segment.target: Password never expires: Select

segment.target: In an elevated Windows PowerShell prompt (run as Administrator), run the following commands and press Enter after each command:

segment.source: Step 2: Set up the MDT production deployment share
segment.target: Step 2: Set up the MDT production deployment share

segment.source: When you are ready to deploy Windows 10 in a production environment, you will first create a new MDT deployment share.
segment.target: When you are ready to deploy Windows 10 in a production environment, you will first create a new MDT deployment share.

segment.source: You should not use the same deployment share that you used to create the reference image for a production deployment.
segment.target: You should not use the same deployment share that you used to create the reference image for a production deployment.

segment.source: For guidance on creating a custom Windows 10 image, see Create a Windows 10 reference image.
segment.target: For guidance on creating a custom Windows 10 image, see Create a Windows 10 reference image.

segment.source: Create the MDT production deployment share
segment.target: Create the MDT production deployment share

segment.source: The steps for creating the deployment share for production are the same as when you created the deployment share for creating the custom reference image:
segment.target: The steps for creating the deployment share for production are the same as when you created the deployment share for creating the custom reference image:

segment.source: On MDT01, log on as Administrator in the CONTOSO domain using a password of P@ssw0rd.
segment.target: On MDT01, log on as Administrator in the CONTOSO domain using a password of P@ssw0rd.

segment.source: Using the Deployment Workbench, right-click Deployment Shares and select New Deployment Share.
segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench, right-click Deployment Shares and select New Deployment Share.

segment.source: On the Path page, in the Deployment share path text box, type E:MDTProduction and click Next.
segment.target: On the Path page, in the Deployment share path text box, type E:MDTProduction and click Next.

segment.source: On the Share page, in the Share name text box, type MDTProduction$ and click Next.
segment.target: On the Share page, in the Share name text box, type MDTProduction$ and click Next.

segment.source: On the Descriptive Name page, in the Deployment share description text box, type MDT Production and click Next.
segment.target: On the Descriptive Name page, in the Deployment share description text box, type MDT Production and click Next.

segment.source: On the Options page, accept the default settings and click Next twice, and then click Finish.
segment.target: On the Options page, accept the default settings and click Next twice, and then click Finish.

segment.source: Using File Explorer, verify that you can access the MDT01MDTProduction$ share.
segment.target: Using File Explorer, verify that you can access the MDT01MDTProduction$ share.

segment.source: Step 3: Add a custom image
segment.target: Step 3: Add a custom image

segment.source: The next step is to add a reference image into the deployment share with the setup files required to successfully deploy Windows 10.
segment.target: The next step is to add a reference image into the deployment share with the setup files required to successfully deploy Windows 10.

segment.source: When adding a custom image, you still need to copy setup files (an option in the wizard) because Windows 10 stores additional components in the SourcesSxS folder which is outside the image and may be required when installing components.
segment.target: When adding a custom image, you still need to copy setup files (an option in the wizard) because Windows 10 stores additional components in the SourcesSxS folder which is outside the image and may be required when installing components.

segment.source: Add the Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM custom image
segment.target: Add the Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM custom image

segment.source: In these steps, we assume that you have completed the steps in the Create a Windows 10 reference image topic, so you have a Windows 10 reference image in the E:MDTBuildLabCaptures folder on MDT01.
segment.target: In these steps, we assume that you have completed the steps in the Create a Windows 10 reference image topic, so you have a Windows 10 reference image in the E:MDTBuildLabCaptures folder on MDT01.

segment.source: Using the Deployment Workbench, expand the Deployment Shares node, and then expand MDT Production; select the Operating Systems node, and create a folder named Windows 10.
segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench, expand the Deployment Shares node, and then expand MDT Production; select the Operating Systems node, and create a folder named Windows 10.

segment.source: Right-click the Windows 10 folder and select Import Operating System.
segment.target: Right-click the Windows 10 folder and select Import Operating System.

segment.source: On the OS Type page, select Custom image file and click Next.
segment.target: On the OS Type page, select Custom image file and click Next.

segment.source: On the Image page, in the Source file text box, browse to E:MDTBuildLabCapturesREFW10X64-001.wim and click Next.
segment.target: On the Image page, in the Source file text box, browse to E:MDTBuildLabCapturesREFW10X64-001.wim and click Next.

segment.source: On the Setup page, select the Copy Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, or later setup files from the specified path option; in the Setup source directory text box, browse to E:MDTBuildLabOperating SystemsW10EX64RTM and click Next.
segment.target: On the Setup page, select the Copy Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, or later setup files from the specified path option; in the Setup source directory text box, browse to E:MDTBuildLabOperating SystemsW10EX64RTM and click Next.

segment.source: On the Destination page, in the Destination directory name text box, type W10EX64RTM, click Next twice, and then click Finish.
segment.target: On the Destination page, in the Destination directory name text box, type W10EX64RTM, click Next twice, and then click Finish.

segment.source: After adding the operating system, double-click the added operating system name in the Operating Systems / Windows 10 node and change the name to match the following: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM Custom Image.
segment.target: After adding the operating system, double-click the added operating system name in the Operating Systems / Windows 10 node and change the name to match the following: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM Custom Image.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The reason for adding the setup files has changed since earlier versions of MDT.
segment.target: The reason for adding the setup files has changed since earlier versions of MDT.

segment.source: MDT 2010 used the setup files to install Windows.
segment.target: MDT 2010 used the setup files to install Windows.

segment.source: MDT uses DISM to apply the image; however, you still need the setup files because some components in roles and features are stored outside the main image.
segment.target: MDT uses DISM to apply the image; however, you still need the setup files because some components in roles and features are stored outside the main image.

segment.source: Step 4: Add an application
segment.target: Step 4: Add an application

segment.source: When you configure your MDT Build Lab deployment share, you will also add any applications to the new deployment share before creating your task sequence.
segment.target: When you configure your MDT Build Lab deployment share, you will also add any applications to the new deployment share before creating your task sequence.

segment.source: This section walks you through the process of adding an application to the MDT Production deployment share using Adobe Reader as an example.
segment.target: This section walks you through the process of adding an application to the MDT Production deployment share using Adobe Reader as an example.

segment.source: Create the install: Adobe Reader XI x86
segment.target: Create the install: Adobe Reader XI x86

segment.source: In this example, we assume that you have downloaded the Adobe Reader XI installation file (AdbeRdr11000euES.msi) to E:SetupAdobe Reader on MDT01.
segment.target: In this example, we assume that you have downloaded the Adobe Reader XI installation file (AdbeRdr11000euES.msi) to E:SetupAdobe Reader on MDT01.

segment.source: Using the Deployment Workbench, expand the MDT Production node and navigate to the Applications node.
segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench, expand the MDT Production node and navigate to the Applications node.

segment.source: Right-click the Applications node, and create a new folder named Adobe.
segment.target: Right-click the Applications node, and create a new folder named Adobe.

segment.source: In the Applications node, right-click the Adobe folder and select New Application.
segment.target: In the Applications node, right-click the Adobe folder and select New Application.

segment.source: On the Application Type page, select the Application with source files option and click Next.
segment.target: On the Application Type page, select the Application with source files option and click Next.

segment.source: On the Details page, in the Application name text box, type Install - Adobe Reader XI - x86 and click Next.
segment.target: On the Details page, in the Application name text box, type Install - Adobe Reader XI - x86 and click Next.

segment.source: On the Source page, in the Source Directory text box, browse to E:SetupAdobe Reader XI and click Next.
segment.target: On the Source page, in the Source Directory text box, browse to E:SetupAdobe Reader XI and click Next.

segment.source: On the Destination page, in the Specify the name of the directory that should be created text box, type Install - Adobe Reader XI - x86 and click Next.
segment.target: On the Destination page, in the Specify the name of the directory that should be created text box, type Install - Adobe Reader XI - x86 and click Next.

segment.source: On the Command Details page, in the Command Line text box, type msiexec /i AdbeRdr11000euES.msi /q, click Next twice, and then click Finish.
segment.target: On the Command Details page, in the Command Line text box, type msiexec /i AdbeRdr11000euES.msi /q, click Next twice, and then click Finish.

segment.source: figure 3
segment.target: figure 3

segment.source: Figure 3.
segment.target: Figure 3.

segment.source: The Adobe Reader application added to the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: The Adobe Reader application added to the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: Step 5: Prepare the drivers repository
segment.target: Step 5: Prepare the drivers repository

segment.source: In order to deploy Windows 10 with MDT 2013 Update 2 successfully, you need drivers for the boot images and for the actual operating system.
segment.target: In order to deploy Windows 10 with MDT 2013 Update 2 successfully, you need drivers for the boot images and for the actual operating system.

segment.source: This section will show you how to add drivers for the boot image and operating system, using the following hardware models as examples:
segment.target: This section will show you how to add drivers for the boot image and operating system, using the following hardware models as examples:

segment.source: Lenovo ThinkPad T420
segment.target: Lenovo ThinkPad T420

segment.source: Dell Latitude E6440
segment.target: Dell Latitude E6440

segment.source: HP EliteBook 8560w
segment.target: HP EliteBook 8560w

segment.source: Microsoft Surface Pro For boot images, you need to have storage and network drivers; for the operating system, you need to have the full suite of drivers.
segment.target: Microsoft Surface Pro For boot images, you need to have storage and network drivers; for the operating system, you need to have the full suite of drivers.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You should only add drivers to the Windows PE images if the default drivers don't work.
segment.target: You should only add drivers to the Windows PE images if the default drivers don't work.

segment.source: Adding drivers that are not necessary will only make the boot image larger and potentially delay the download time.
segment.target: Adding drivers that are not necessary will only make the boot image larger and potentially delay the download time.

segment.source: Create the driver source structure in the file system
segment.target: Create the driver source structure in the file system

segment.source: The key to successful management of drivers for MDT 2013 Update 2, as well as for any other deployment solution, is to have a really good driver repository.
segment.target: The key to successful management of drivers for MDT 2013 Update 2, as well as for any other deployment solution, is to have a really good driver repository.

segment.source: From this repository, you import drivers into MDT for deployment, but you should always maintain the repository for future use.
segment.target: From this repository, you import drivers into MDT for deployment, but you should always maintain the repository for future use.

segment.source: On MDT01, using File Explorer, create the E:Drivers folder.
segment.target: On MDT01, using File Explorer, create the E:Drivers folder.

segment.target: In the E:Drivers folder, create the following folder structure:

segment.target: In the new Windows 10 x64 folder, create the following folder structure:

segment.source: Create the logical driver structure in MDT 2013 Update 2
segment.target: Create the logical driver structure in MDT 2013 Update 2

segment.source: When you import drivers to the MDT 2013 Update 2 driver repository, MDT creates a single instance folder structure based on driver class names.
segment.target: When you import drivers to the MDT 2013 Update 2 driver repository, MDT creates a single instance folder structure based on driver class names.

segment.source: However, you can, and should, mimic the driver structure of your driver source repository in the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: However, you can, and should, mimic the driver structure of your driver source repository in the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: This is done by creating logical folders in the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: This is done by creating logical folders in the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: Create the selection profiles for boot image drivers
segment.target: Create the selection profiles for boot image drivers

segment.source: By default, MDT adds any storage and network drivers that you import to the boot images.
segment.target: By default, MDT adds any storage and network drivers that you import to the boot images.

segment.source: However, you should add only the drivers that are necessary to the boot image.
segment.target: However, you should add only the drivers that are necessary to the boot image.

segment.source: You can control which drivers are added by using selection profiles.
segment.target: You can control which drivers are added by using selection profiles.

segment.source: The drivers that are used for the boot images (Windows PE) are Windows 10 drivers.
segment.target: The drivers that are used for the boot images (Windows PE) are Windows 10 drivers.

segment.source: If you can’t locate Windows 10 drivers for your device, a Windows 7 or Windows 8.1 driver will most likely work, but Windows 10 drivers should be your first choice.
segment.target: If you can’t locate Windows 10 drivers for your device, a Windows 7 or Windows 8.1 driver will most likely work, but Windows 10 drivers should be your first choice.

segment.source: On MDT01, using the Deployment Workbench, in the MDT Production node, expand the Advanced Configuration node, right-click the Selection Profiles node, and select New Selection Profile.
segment.target: On MDT01, using the Deployment Workbench, in the MDT Production node, expand the Advanced Configuration node, right-click the Selection Profiles node, and select New Selection Profile.

segment.source: Extract and import drivers for the x64 boot image
segment.target: Extract and import drivers for the x64 boot image

segment.source: Windows PE supports all the hardware models that we have, but here you learn to add boot image drivers to accommodate any new hardware that might require additional drivers.
segment.target: Windows PE supports all the hardware models that we have, but here you learn to add boot image drivers to accommodate any new hardware that might require additional drivers.

segment.source: In this example, you add the latest Intel network drivers to the x64 boot image.
segment.target: In this example, you add the latest Intel network drivers to the x64 boot image.

segment.source: In these steps, we assume you have downloaded PROWinx64.exe from Intel.com and saved it to a temporary folder.
segment.target: In these steps, we assume you have downloaded PROWinx64.exe from Intel.com and saved it to a temporary folder.

segment.source: Extract PROWinx64.exe to a temporary folder - in this example to the C:TmpProWinx64 folder.
segment.target: Extract PROWinx64.exe to a temporary folder - in this example to the C:TmpProWinx64 folder.

segment.source: Using File Explorer, create the E:DriversWinPE x64Intel PRO1000 folder.
segment.target: Using File Explorer, create the E:DriversWinPE x64Intel PRO1000 folder.

segment.source: Copy the content of the C:TmpPROWinx64PRO1000Winx64NDIS64 folder to the E:DriversWinPE x64Intel PRO1000 folder.
segment.target: Copy the content of the C:TmpPROWinx64PRO1000Winx64NDIS64 folder to the E:DriversWinPE x64Intel PRO1000 folder.

segment.source: Using Deployment Workbench, expand the Out-of-Box Drivers node, right-click the WinPE x64 node, and select Import Drivers.
segment.target: Using Deployment Workbench, expand the Out-of-Box Drivers node, right-click the WinPE x64 node, and select Import Drivers.

segment.source: Use the following setting for the Import Drivers Wizard:
segment.target: Use the following setting for the Import Drivers Wizard:

segment.source: Driver source directory: E:DriversWinPE x64Intel PRO1000
segment.target: Driver source directory: E:DriversWinPE x64Intel PRO1000

segment.source: Download, extract, and import drivers
segment.target: Download, extract, and import drivers

segment.source: For the ThinkPad T420
segment.target: For the ThinkPad T420

segment.source: For the Lenovo T420 model, you use the Lenovo ThinkVantage Update Retriever software to download the drivers.
segment.target: For the Lenovo T420 model, you use the Lenovo ThinkVantage Update Retriever software to download the drivers.

segment.source: With Update Retriever, you need to specify the correct Lenovo Machine Type for the actual hardware (the first four characters of the model name).
segment.target: With Update Retriever, you need to specify the correct Lenovo Machine Type for the actual hardware (the first four characters of the model name).

segment.source: As an example, the Lenovo T420 model has the 4178B9G model name, meaning the Machine Type is 4178.
segment.target: As an example, the Lenovo T420 model has the 4178B9G model name, meaning the Machine Type is 4178.

segment.source: To get the updates, you download the drivers from the Lenovo ThinkVantage Update Retriever using its export function.
segment.target: To get the updates, you download the drivers from the Lenovo ThinkVantage Update Retriever using its export function.

segment.source: You can download the drivers from the Lenovo website.
segment.target: You can download the drivers from the Lenovo website.

segment.source: In these steps, we assume you have downloaded and extracted the drivers using ThinkVantage Update Retriever v5.0 to the E:DriversLenovoThinkPad T420 (4178) folder.
segment.target: In these steps, we assume you have downloaded and extracted the drivers using ThinkVantage Update Retriever v5.0 to the E:DriversLenovoThinkPad T420 (4178) folder.

segment.source: The rules explained
segment.target: The rules explained

segment.source: The rules for the MDT Production deployment share are somewhat different from those for the MDT Build Lab deployment share.
segment.target: The rules for the MDT Production deployment share are somewhat different from those for the MDT Build Lab deployment share.

segment.source: The biggest differences are that you deploy the machines into a domain instead of a workgroup and that you do not automate the logon.
segment.target: The biggest differences are that you deploy the machines into a domain instead of a workgroup and that you do not automate the logon.

segment.source: If your organization has a Microsoft Software Assurance agreement, you also can subscribe to the additional Microsoft Desktop Optimization Package (MDOP) license (at an additional cost).
segment.target: If your organization has a Microsoft Software Assurance agreement, you also can subscribe to the additional Microsoft Desktop Optimization Package (MDOP) license (at an additional cost).

segment.source: Included in MDOP is Microsoft Diagnostics and Recovery Toolkit (DaRT), which contains tools that can help you troubleshoot MDT deployments, as well as troubleshoot Windows itself.
segment.target: Included in MDOP is Microsoft Diagnostics and Recovery Toolkit (DaRT), which contains tools that can help you troubleshoot MDT deployments, as well as troubleshoot Windows itself.

segment.source: Add DaRT 10 to the boot images
segment.target: Add DaRT 10 to the boot images

segment.source: If you have licensing for MDOP and DaRT, you can add DaRT to the boot images using the steps in this section.
segment.target: If you have licensing for MDOP and DaRT, you can add DaRT to the boot images using the steps in this section.

segment.source: If you do not have DaRT licensing, or don't want to use it, simply skip to the next section, Update the Deployment Share.
segment.target: If you do not have DaRT licensing, or don't want to use it, simply skip to the next section, Update the Deployment Share.

segment.source: Install DaRT 10 (part of MDOP 2015 R1).
segment.target: Install DaRT 10 (part of MDOP 2015 R1).

segment.target: Copy the two tools CAB files (Toolsx86.cab and Toolsx64.cab) to the deployment share.

segment.target: Configure the deployment share to add DaRT.

segment.source: Step 8: Deploy the Windows 10 client image
segment.target: Step 8: Deploy the Windows 10 client image

segment.source: These steps will walk you throug the process of using task sequences to deploy Windows 10 images through a fully automated process.
segment.target: These steps will walk you throug the process of using task sequences to deploy Windows 10 images through a fully automated process.

segment.source: First, you need to add the boot image to Windows Deployment Services (WDS) and then start the deployment.
segment.target: First, you need to add the boot image to Windows Deployment Services (WDS) and then start the deployment.

segment.source: In contrast with deploying images from the MDT Build Lab deployment share, we recommend using the Pre-Installation Execution Environment (PXE) to start the full deployments in the datacenter, even though you technically can use an ISO/CD or USB to start the process.
segment.target: In contrast with deploying images from the MDT Build Lab deployment share, we recommend using the Pre-Installation Execution Environment (PXE) to start the full deployments in the datacenter, even though you technically can use an ISO/CD or USB to start the process.

segment.source: Configure Windows Deployment Services
segment.target: Configure Windows Deployment Services

segment.source: You need to add the MDT Production Lite Touch x64 Boot image to WDS in preparation for the deployment.
segment.target: You need to add the MDT Production Lite Touch x64 Boot image to WDS in preparation for the deployment.

segment.source: For the following steps, we assume that Windows Deployment Services has already been installed on MDT01.
segment.target: For the following steps, we assume that Windows Deployment Services has already been installed on MDT01.

segment.source: Using the WDS console, right-click Boot Images and select Add Boot Image.
segment.target: Using the WDS console, right-click Boot Images and select Add Boot Image.

segment.source: Browse to the E:MDTProductionBootLiteTouchPEx64.wim file and add the image with the default settings.
segment.target: Browse to the E:MDTProductionBootLiteTouchPEx64.wim file and add the image with the default settings.

segment.source: Deploy the Windows 10 client
segment.target: Deploy the Windows 10 client

segment.source: At this point, you should have a solution ready for deploying the Windows 10 client.
segment.target: At this point, you should have a solution ready for deploying the Windows 10 client.

segment.source: We recommend starting by trying a few deployments at a time until you are confident that your configuration works as expected.
segment.target: We recommend starting by trying a few deployments at a time until you are confident that your configuration works as expected.

segment.source: We find it useful to try some initial tests on virtual machines before testing on physical hardware.
segment.target: We find it useful to try some initial tests on virtual machines before testing on physical hardware.

segment.source: This helps rule out hardware issues when testing or troubleshooting.
segment.target: This helps rule out hardware issues when testing or troubleshooting.

segment.source: Multicast deployments
segment.target: Multicast deployments

segment.source: Multicast deployment allows for image deployment with reduced network load during simultaneous deployments.
segment.target: Multicast deployment allows for image deployment with reduced network load during simultaneous deployments.

segment.source: Multicast is a useful operating system deployment feature in MDT deployments, however it is important to ensure that your network supports it and is designed for it.
segment.target: Multicast is a useful operating system deployment feature in MDT deployments, however it is important to ensure that your network supports it and is designed for it.

segment.source: Requirements
segment.target: Requirements

segment.source: Multicast requires that Windows Deployment Services (WDS) is running on Windows Server 2008 or later.
segment.target: Multicast requires that Windows Deployment Services (WDS) is running on Windows Server 2008 or later.

segment.source: In addition to the core MDT 2013 setup for multicast, the network needs to be configured to support multicast.
segment.target: In addition to the core MDT 2013 setup for multicast, the network needs to be configured to support multicast.

segment.source: In general, this means involving the organization networking team to make sure that Internet Group Management Protocol (IGMP) snooping is turned on and that the network is designed for multicast traffic.
segment.target: In general, this means involving the organization networking team to make sure that Internet Group Management Protocol (IGMP) snooping is turned on and that the network is designed for multicast traffic.

segment.source: The multicast solution uses IGMPv3.
segment.target: The multicast solution uses IGMPv3.

segment.source: Set up MDT for multicast
segment.target: Set up MDT for multicast

segment.source: Setting up MDT for multicast is straightforward.
segment.target: Setting up MDT for multicast is straightforward.

segment.source: You enable multicast on the deployment share, and MDT takes care of the rest.
segment.target: You enable multicast on the deployment share, and MDT takes care of the rest.

segment.source: On MDT01, right-click the MDT Production deployment share folder and select Properties.
segment.target: On MDT01, right-click the MDT Production deployment share folder and select Properties.

segment.source: In the General tab, select the Enable multicast for this deployment share (requires Windows Server 2008 R2 Windows Deployment Services) check box, and click OK.
segment.target: In the General tab, select the Enable multicast for this deployment share (requires Windows Server 2008 R2 Windows Deployment Services) check box, and click OK.

segment.source: Right-click the MDT Production deployment share folder and select Update Deployment Share.
segment.target: Right-click the MDT Production deployment share folder and select Update Deployment Share.

segment.source: After updating the deployment share, use the Windows Deployment Services console to, verify that the multicast namespace was created.
segment.target: After updating the deployment share, use the Windows Deployment Services console to, verify that the multicast namespace was created.

segment.source: Use offline media to deploy Windows 10
segment.target: Use offline media to deploy Windows 10

segment.source: In addition to network-based deployments, MDT supports the use of offline media-based deployments of Windows 10.
segment.target: In addition to network-based deployments, MDT supports the use of offline media-based deployments of Windows 10.

segment.source: You can very easily generate an offline version of your deployment share - either the full deployment share or a subset of it - by the use of selection profiles.
segment.target: You can very easily generate an offline version of your deployment share - either the full deployment share or a subset of it - by the use of selection profiles.

segment.source: The generated offline media can be burned to a DVD or copied to a USB stick for deployment.
segment.target: The generated offline media can be burned to a DVD or copied to a USB stick for deployment.

segment.source: Offline media are useful not only when you do not have network connectivity to the deployment share, but also when you have limited connection to the deployment share and do not want to copy 5 GB of data over the wire.
segment.target: Offline media are useful not only when you do not have network connectivity to the deployment share, but also when you have limited connection to the deployment share and do not want to copy 5 GB of data over the wire.

segment.source: Offline media can still join the domain, but you save the transfer of operating system images, drivers, and applications over the wire.
segment.target: Offline media can still join the domain, but you save the transfer of operating system images, drivers, and applications over the wire.

segment.source: Create the offline media selection profile
segment.target: Create the offline media selection profile

segment.source: To filter what is being added to the media, you create a selection profile.
segment.target: To filter what is being added to the media, you create a selection profile.

segment.source: When creating selection profiles, you quickly realize the benefits of having created a good logical folder structure in the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: When creating selection profiles, you quickly realize the benefits of having created a good logical folder structure in the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: On MDT01, using Deployment Workbench, in the MDT Production / Advanced Configuration node, right-click Selection Profile, and select New Selection Profile.
segment.target: On MDT01, using Deployment Workbench, in the MDT Production / Advanced Configuration node, right-click Selection Profile, and select New Selection Profile.

segment.source: Use the following settings for the New Selection Profile Wizard:
segment.target: Use the following settings for the New Selection Profile Wizard:

segment.source: General Settings
segment.target: General Settings

segment.source: Selection profile name: Windows 10 Offline Media
segment.target: Selection profile name: Windows 10 Offline Media

segment.source: Folders
segment.target: Folders

segment.source: Applications / Adobe
segment.target: Applications / Adobe

segment.source: Operating Systems / Windows 10
segment.target: Operating Systems / Windows 10

segment.target: Out-Of-Box Drivers / WinPE x64

segment.target: Out-Of-Box Drivers / Windows 10 x64

segment.target: Task Sequences / Windows 10

segment.source: Create the offline media
segment.target: Create the offline media

segment.source: In these steps, you generate offline media from the MDT Production deployment share.
segment.target: In these steps, you generate offline media from the MDT Production deployment share.

segment.source: To filter what is being added to the media, you use the previously created selection profile.
segment.target: To filter what is being added to the media, you use the previously created selection profile.

segment.source: On MDT01, using File Explorer, create the E:MDTOfflineMedia folder.
segment.target: On MDT01, using File Explorer, create the E:MDTOfflineMedia folder.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: When creating offline media, you need to create the target folder first.
segment.target: When creating offline media, you need to create the target folder first.

segment.source: It is crucial that you do not create a subfolder inside the deployment share folder because it will break the offline media.
segment.target: It is crucial that you do not create a subfolder inside the deployment share folder because it will break the offline media.

segment.source: Using Deployment Workbench, in the MDT Production / Advanced Configuration node, right-click the Media node, and select New Media.
segment.target: Using Deployment Workbench, in the MDT Production / Advanced Configuration node, right-click the Media node, and select New Media.

segment.source: Use the following settings for the New Media Wizard:
segment.target: Use the following settings for the New Media Wizard:

segment.source: General Settings
segment.target: General Settings

segment.source: Media path: E:MDTOfflineMedia
segment.target: Media path: E:MDTOfflineMedia

segment.source: Selection profile: Windows 10 Offline Media
segment.target: Selection profile: Windows 10 Offline Media

segment.source: Configure the offline media
segment.target: Configure the offline media

segment.source: Offline media has its own rules, its own Bootstrap.ini and CustomSettings.ini files.
segment.target: Offline media has its own rules, its own Bootstrap.ini and CustomSettings.ini files.

segment.source: These files are stored in the Control folder of the offline media; they also can be accessed via properties of the offline media in the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: These files are stored in the Control folder of the offline media; they also can be accessed via properties of the offline media in the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: On MDT01, using File Explorer, copy the CustomSettings.ini file from the E:MDTBuildLabControl folder to E:MDTOfflineMediaContentDeployControl.
segment.target: On MDT01, using File Explorer, copy the CustomSettings.ini file from the E:MDTBuildLabControl folder to E:MDTOfflineMediaContentDeployControl.

segment.source: Overwrite the existing files.
segment.target: Overwrite the existing files.

segment.source: Using Deployment Workbench, in the MDT Production / Advanced Configuration / Media node, right-click the MEDIA001 media, and select Properties.
segment.target: Using Deployment Workbench, in the MDT Production / Advanced Configuration / Media node, right-click the MEDIA001 media, and select Properties.

segment.source: In the General tab, configure the following:
segment.target: In the General tab, configure the following:

segment.source: Clear the Generate x86 boot image check box.
segment.target: Clear the Generate x86 boot image check box.

segment.source: ISO file name: Windows 10 Offline Media.iso
segment.target: ISO file name: Windows 10 Offline Media.iso

segment.source: Still in the Windows PE tab, in the Platform drop-down list, select x64.
segment.target: Still in the Windows PE tab, in the Platform drop-down list, select x64.

segment.source: In the General sub tab, configure the following settings:
segment.target: In the General sub tab, configure the following settings:

segment.source: In the Lite Touch Boot Image Settings area:
segment.target: In the Lite Touch Boot Image Settings area:

segment.source: Image description: MDT Production x64
segment.target: Image description: MDT Production x64

segment.source: In the Windows PE Customizations area, set the Scratch space size to 128.
segment.target: In the Windows PE Customizations area, set the Scratch space size to 128.

segment.source: In the Drivers and Patches sub tab, select the WinPE x64 selection profile and select the Include all drivers from the selection profile option.
segment.target: In the Drivers and Patches sub tab, select the WinPE x64 selection profile and select the Include all drivers from the selection profile option.

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: Generate the offline media
segment.target: Generate the offline media

segment.source: You have now configured the offline media deployment share however the share has not yet been populated with the files required for deployment.
segment.target: You have now configured the offline media deployment share however the share has not yet been populated with the files required for deployment.

segment.source: Now everything is ready you populate the deployment share content folder and generate the offline media ISO.
segment.target: Now everything is ready you populate the deployment share content folder and generate the offline media ISO.

segment.source: On MDT01, using Deployment Workbench, navigate to the MDT Production / Advanced Configuration / Media node.
segment.target: On MDT01, using Deployment Workbench, navigate to the MDT Production / Advanced Configuration / Media node.

segment.source: Right-click the MEDIA001 media, and select Update Media Content.
segment.target: Right-click the MEDIA001 media, and select Update Media Content.

segment.source: The Update Media Content process now generates the offline media in the E:MDTOfflineMediaContent folder.
segment.target: The Update Media Content process now generates the offline media in the E:MDTOfflineMediaContent folder.

segment.source: Create a bootable USB stick
segment.target: Create a bootable USB stick

segment.source: The ISO that you got when updating the offline media item can be burned to a DVD and used directly (it will be bootable), but it is often more efficient to use USB sticks instead since they are faster and can hold more data.
segment.target: The ISO that you got when updating the offline media item can be burned to a DVD and used directly (it will be bootable), but it is often more efficient to use USB sticks instead since they are faster and can hold more data.

segment.source: (A dual-layer DVD is limited to 8.5 GB.) Follow these steps to create a bootable USB stick from the offline media content:
segment.target: (A dual-layer DVD is limited to 8.5 GB.) Follow these steps to create a bootable USB stick from the offline media content:

segment.source: On a physical machine running Windows 7 or later, insert the USB stick you want to use.
segment.target: On a physical machine running Windows 7 or later, insert the USB stick you want to use.

segment.source: Copy the content of the MDTOfflineMediaContent folder to the root of the USB stick.
segment.target: Copy the content of the MDTOfflineMediaContent folder to the root of the USB stick.

segment.source: Start an elevated command prompt (run as Administrator), and start the Diskpart utility by typing Diskpart and pressing Enter.
segment.target: Start an elevated command prompt (run as Administrator), and start the Diskpart utility by typing Diskpart and pressing Enter.

segment.source: In the Diskpart utility, you can type list volume (or the shorter list vol) to list the volumes, but you really only need to remember the drive letter of the USB stick to which you copied the content.
segment.target: In the Diskpart utility, you can type list volume (or the shorter list vol) to list the volumes, but you really only need to remember the drive letter of the USB stick to which you copied the content.

segment.source: In our example, the USB stick had the drive letter F.
segment.target: In our example, the USB stick had the drive letter F.

segment.source: In the Diskpart utility, type select volume F (replace F with your USB stick drive letter).
segment.target: In the Diskpart utility, type select volume F (replace F with your USB stick drive letter).

segment.source: In the Diskpart utility, type active, and then type exit.
segment.target: In the Diskpart utility, type active, and then type exit.

segment.source: Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI)-based deployments
segment.target: Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI)-based deployments

segment.source: As referenced in Windows 10 deployment tools, Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI)-based deployments are becoming more common.
segment.target: As referenced in Windows 10 deployment tools, Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI)-based deployments are becoming more common.

segment.source: In fact, when you create a generation 2 virtual machine in Hyper-V, you get a UEFI-based computer.
segment.target: In fact, when you create a generation 2 virtual machine in Hyper-V, you get a UEFI-based computer.

segment.source: During deployment, MDT automatically detects that you have an UEFI-based machine and creates the partitions UEFI requires.
segment.target: During deployment, MDT automatically detects that you have an UEFI-based machine and creates the partitions UEFI requires.

segment.source: You do not need to update or change your task sequences in any way to accommodate UFEI.
segment.target: You do not need to update or change your task sequences in any way to accommodate UFEI.
